title: 107_hr1621
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001". The Arabia Mountain area contains natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources that represent the heritage of the United States. Managing these resources through partnerships between public and private entities is recommended. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in Georgia protects various ecosystems and federally-protected plant species. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia protects granite outcrop ecosystems, wetlands, and pine and oak forests, including federally-protected plant species. Panola Mountain in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park is a rare example of a pristine granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve along the South River contains evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain showcase the history of granite mining in Georgia and its impact on the United States. The South River contains evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain display the history of granite mining in Georgia and its impact on the United States. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation. Lithonia has 2 structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites and communities. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, promote, interpret, and make available natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites and communities. It also aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing and implementing a cultural, historical, and land resource management program to protect and enhance the significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Heritage area - Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area.
(2) Management entity - Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance or successor.
(3) Management plan - plan for the heritage area developed under section 6.
(4) Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.
(5) State - State of Georgia.

SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. Establishment of the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance will be the management entity for the heritage area. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests within the area and establishes priorities. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and implementing a management plan that considers diverse interests within the area and establishes priorities, including assisting in resource preservation and encouraging land use policies consistent with the goals of the plan. Public meetings are also conducted by the management entity. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is responsible for preserving resources, encouraging land use policies, conducting quarterly public meetings, submitting annual reports on accomplishments and expenses, and making audit information available to the Secretary. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must submit an annual report detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to make all records available for audit by the Secretary, including those related to the expenditure of Federal funds and any matching funds. Additionally, Federal funds provided under this Act cannot be used to acquire real estate. The management entity must provide records for audit to the Secretary regarding the expenditure of funds. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real property. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources in the area. The management plan for the heritage area must involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations. It should include an inventory of resources, provisions for protection and interpretation, and an interpretation plan for the area. The management plan for the heritage area includes an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation, an interpretation plan, a program for implementation, and a description of the management entity. The management plan for the heritage area includes assessment of cultural landscapes, protection and interpretation provisions, funding sources identification, evaluation of the management entity, and submission to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. The management plan for the heritage area must be submitted to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. If not submitted on time, additional funding will be withheld until the plan is submitted. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it, and if disapproved, the management entity will be advised to revise it. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the management plan within 90 days. If disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and recommendations for revisions, allowing the management entity to submit revised plan within 90 days. After approval of a management plan, the management entity can periodically review and submit recommendations for revisions to the Secretary for approval within 90 days. The management entity must review and submit recommendations for revisions to the Secretary for approval before implementing any proposed changes using funds from this Act. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing actions that conserve natural, cultural, and historical resources. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50%. Secretary's authority to grant assistance terminates on September 30, 2016.
